statements.text: Kinetic energy is calculated using the formula E_k = 1/2 mv^2
Kinetic energy is measured in Joules
Kinetic energy decreases as velocity increases
Work done is calculated using the formula W = Fd
Work done is measured in Newtons
Work is energy transferred
Gravitational potential energy is calculated using E_p = mgΔh
Gravitational potential energy increases as height increases
Gravitational potential energy is independent of mass
In a frictionless system, E_p = E_k
Energy can be created or destroyed in a closed system
The total energy in a closed system remains constant
Final speed can be calculated using the equation E_p = E_k
The equation v = √(2gh) can be derived from E_p = E_k
The final speed of a falling object is less than its initial speed in a fall
The relationship between power, energy, and time is E = Pt
Power is measured in Watts
Energy is the rate at which work is done
Efficiency is always expressed as a percentage
An efficiency of 100% means all input energy is converted to useful output
Efficiency can be greater than 100% in some machines
Force is measured in Newtons
Energy is measured in Joules
Power is measured in Newtons per second
The acceleration due to gravity on Earth is approximately 9.8 ms^-2
Gravity is sometimes rounded to 10 ms^-2 for calculations
Gravity is the same everywhere on Earth's surface
Kinetic energy can be converted to gravitational potential energy
Energy conversions always involve some energy loss to heat
It's impossible to convert gravitational potential energy to kinetic energy
In a series circuit, the current is the same throughout the circuit
In a parallel circuit, the voltage is the same across each parallel branch
In a series circuit, the total resistance is less than any individual resistor
Ohm's Law is expressed as V = IR
The unit of resistance (R) is the ohm (Ω)
Ohm's Law applies to all electrical components
The relationship between energy, power, and time is expressed as E = Pt
Energy is measured in joules (J)
Power is measured in watts per second (W/s)
Current is measured in amperes (A)
Voltage is the pressure that pushes electric charges through a wire
Resistance is measured in watts (W)
Power can be calculated using the formula P = IV
Power is the rate at which energy is transferred
The unit of power is the joule (J)
Electrical energy is converted to heat in a resistor
The amount of heat produced is independent of the current flowing through the resistor
This conversion in a resistor is an example of the law of conservation of energy
Batteries convert chemical energy to electrical energy
The voltage of a battery depends on its chemical composition
Batteries can convert electrical energy back into chemical energy indefinitely
Efficiency is calculated by dividing output power by input power
An electrical system can have an efficiency greater than 100%
Improving efficiency can reduce energy waste and costs
The total resistance in a series circuit is the sum of individual resistances
The formula for total resistance in series is R_t = R_1 + R_2 + ...
Adding resistors in series always decreases the total resistance
Conductors have low resistance to electric current
Insulators have high resistance to electric current
All metals are good conductors, and all non-metals are good insulators
The formula E = mcΔT is used to calculate energy transfer during temperature changes
'c' in the formula represents specific heat capacity
The unit for specific heat capacity is J/kg
The formula E = mL is used when a substance changes phase
'L' represents the latent heat of the substance
Latent heat is the energy required to change the temperature of a substance
Conduction involves the transfer of heat through direct contact
Convection can only occur in liquids
Radiation does not require a medium for heat transfer
Increasing temperature increases the average kinetic energy of particles
In a gas, all particles have exactly the same kinetic energy
Kinetic energy of particles is related to their speed
Heat always flows from a hotter object to a colder object
The rate of heat transfer depends on the temperature difference
Heat transfer will continue until the objects reach different temperatures
Friction always produces heat
The amount of heat produced by friction is independent of the force applied
Friction can convert mechanical energy into thermal energy
A heating curve shows the relationship between temperature and time or energy added
During a phase change, the temperature of a substance remains constant
The slope of a heating curve is always positive
Most materials expand when heated
The degree of expansion is the same for all materials
Thermal expansion can cause bridges to lengthen in summer
Thermal equilibrium is reached when two objects have the same temperature
Heat transfer stops when thermal equilibrium is reached
Thermal equilibrium can only be achieved between solids
Insulation reduces heat transfer
The effectiveness of insulation depends on its thickness and material properties
A perfect insulator would completely stop all forms of heat transfer
The electric field lines in a uniform electric field are parallel and equally spaced.
The force experienced by a charge in a uniform electric field is constant in magnitude and direction.
The electric field strength acting on a charge in a uniform field changes as it moves.
Electric field strength is a vector quantity measured in newtons per coulomb (N/C).
The electric field strength at a point is defined as the force per unit charge experienced by a positive test charge placed at that point.
The electric field strength between two parallel plates is directly proportional to the distance between the plates.
The force on a positive charge in an electric field is in the same direction as the electric field.
The magnitude of the force on a charge in an electric field is given by F = qE, where q is the charge and E is the electric field strength.
The force on a charge in an electric field is always attractive, regardless of the charge's sign.
Electric potential energy is a scalar quantity measured in joules (J).
The change in electric potential energy of a charge moving in an electric field depends only on its initial and final positions, not on the path taken.
Electric potential energy always increases when a positive charge moves in the direction of the electric field.
The work done by an electric field on a charge is equal to the change in the charge's kinetic energy.
The work done by an electric field on a charge is always positive, regardless of the direction of motion.
The work done by an electric field on a charge moving at a constant speed perpendicular to the field lines is zero.
In a circuit diagram, a line connecting components represents a wire with negligible resistance.
A rectangle (or a zigzag) symbol represents a resistor in a circuit diagram.
The symbol for a battery in a circuit diagram has the shorter line on the positive terminal side.
The current through a series circuit is the same at all points.
The sum of the voltage drops across components in a parallel branch always equals the voltage of the power source.
In a circuit diagram, components connected to the same two points are in parallel.
In a series circuit, the total resistance is the sum of individual resistances.
The current is the same through each component in a series circuit.
The voltage across each component in a series circuit is always equal.
For parallel branches, the voltage across each branch is the same.
The total current for parallel barnches is less than the current through any individual branch.
The reciprocal of the total resistance in a parallel circuit equals the sum of the reciprocals of individual resistances.
In a combined circuit, Kirchhoff's voltage law states that the sum of voltage drops around any closed loop is zero.
Kirchhoff's current law states that the sum of currents entering a junction equals the sum of currents leaving it.
The equivalent resistance of a combined circuit is always less than the largest individual resistance in the circuit.
Voltage is a measure of the potential difference between two points in a circuit.
The SI unit of voltage is the volt (V), which is equivalent to joules per coulomb (J/C).
Voltage is always conserved in a circuit, meaning the sum of voltages around any loop must be positive.
Electric current is defined as the rate of flow of charge past a point in a circuit.
The SI unit of current is the ampere (A), which is equivalent to energy per second (J/s).
In a combined circuit with multiple resistors, the current is not always highest through the resistor with the least resistance.
The simplified formula for the equivalent resistance of two resistors in parallel is R_eq = (R1 * R2) / (R1 + R2).
For resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance.
The equivalent resistance of resistors in series is not always greater than the largest individual resistance.
In a circuit made of wires with no resistance, all electrical energy is converted to light energy in the bulbs.
The energy dissipated as heat in a resistor is given by E = I²Rt, where I is current, R is resistance, and t is time.
The energy transferred in an electrical circuit is measured in joules (J).
Electrical power is measured in watts (W), which is equivalent to joules per second (J/s).
In a series circuit, the power dissipated is always equally distributed among all resistors.
The power dissipated in a resistor can be calculated using P = VI, where V is voltage and I is current.
The force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is maximum when the conductor is perpendicular to the field.
The direction of the force can be determined using the right hand slap rule.
The magnitude of the force is directly proportional to the square of the current in the conductor.
The magnetic force on a charged particle moving in a magnetic field is always perpendicular to both the velocity of the particle and the magnetic field.
The magnitude of the magnetic force on a charged particle is given by F = vB sin θ, where v is velocity, B is magnetic field strength, and θ is the angle between v and B.
A charged particle moving parallel to a magnetic field experiences no magnetic force.
In a simple DC motor, the commutator reverses the current direction in the coil every half rotation.
The torque on the coil of a DC motor is maximum when the coil’s velocity is parallel to the magnetic field.
Increasing the number of turns in the coil of a DC motor increases its torque.
The induced voltage in a conductor moving through a magnetic field is directly proportional to the conductor's length, velocity, and the magnetic field strength.
The positive side of the induced voltage can be determined using right hand slap rule.
The induced voltage is maximum when the conductor moves at 45 degrees to the magnetic field lines.
The frequency of the output voltage in a generator is indepenednt of the rotation speed of the coil.
A simple AC generator produces a sinusoidal output voltage.
In a simple generator, the maximum induced voltage occurs when the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field.
